Thank You, Suboxone.. My addiction started 7 years ago at age 22. My attempt to quit started 3 years ago. I would go 14 days, relapse. 30 days, relapse. Then I found Kratom. It allowed me to hit my longest streak - 60 days - but then, yup, relapse.

2 years ago I went overseas for 4 months to get clean. I felt great sober - back to my old, laughing, smiling self. 4 months clean! Yet I relapsed a week after coming back.

Fast forward a year of using, my parents found out (again). Send me abroad again (Middle East). This time she begged me to see a specialist. I was reluctant. I knew what he was going to do - put me on Suboxone. I thought to myself, "Why would I get on suboxone, considering I'm already a month clean?" 

Then I realized why. The relapses. The going to work in Withdrawal. The embarrassment of my boss finding me nodded out at my desk. The trust I lost with my parents, my brothers, myself. The complete stall in my career. The $12 in my bank account, when I was making $800 a week. The waking up in misery. That deep, dark, gut feeling that withdraw is coming. So so many reasons.

I saw the doctor in May and began Suboxone, along with therapy. A month later I flew back home. This time I was stronger, thinking clearer. I'm happy to say it'll soon be 8 months away from Heroin & Oxy. I turn 30 next week, so I'm happy to leave the drug use in my 20s.

I'm not sure I would have done it without Suboxone, & the lessons of therapy. I owe my life to this medication. I have thousands saved, not working yet but studying for my Internal Audit certificate. Something I would have NEVER done during my usage. So, thank you Suboxone. Really. I'm doing so much better.

Thank you to whoever took the time to read this! 12.26.19

Sublocade taper. I've had several hundred patients taper off buprenorphine over the past 15 years -- most after at least 3-5 years on the medication.  Most have done well, but now and then I'll read or hear about a death by overdose of a former patient.  Tapering is possible, but it isn't for everyone.

Lately though I've been using Sublocade as a 'last shot and done' approach.   If you look at the data, it looks promising.  I wouldn't recommend it for people who are still taking over 8 mg per day, because you would need 300 mg of Sublocade to avoid withdrawal the first month, and the drop-off in blood levels is steep enough to cause withdrawal after a few months...  but when a person is down to 4 mg or less, I can give about 50 mg of Sublocade, which then tapers itself over a year.   Studies of higher doses show the blood level constant for about 8 weeks, then gradually falling to zero at about 52 weeks at a constant rate of decline.

I apologize if I missed a post about using it in this way - has anyone out there tried this approach?

Unforeseen downside to using Vitamin C to eliminate my withdrawals. When I first posted how well pure Vitamin C powder worked for eliminating physical withdrawal symptoms. There was one gentleman who commented and said that he *needed* to experience the pain of the withdrawal process as it would later be the thing that would keep him from ever going back. I admired his strength and tenacity but I couldn't understand why someone would want to experience such horrific withdrawal symptoms if they didn't have to. I just couldn't understand it. But now, I do. 

I should start by saying that yes, of course Vitamin C powder does not work for everyone because nothing does. But it does work far more often than not if used in the right form (pure powder) and a high enough dose. For me it was an absolute Godsend. I tried and failed so many times before I discovered Vitamin C. I was on 24mg/day of Suboxone and I was able to rapidly taper all the way down to 2mg in just a few weeks and jump straight off from there with very mild discomfort. My prior attempts without Vitamin C were pure agony and I never made it past day 5. But with high/frequent doses of Vitamin C powder, 80% of my withdrawal symptoms (including RLS, extreme fatigue and cold sweats) would completely subside for a solid 4 hours until my next dose. 

By day 20 I was feeling better physically than I had during the whole time that I was on Suboxone. I was no longer taking the Vitamin C at this point because I just didn't need it. When my dose of Vitamin C would wear off and no withdrawal symptoms would creep up, that's when I knew I had fully made it through the physical aspect. 

By day 30, I don't think I had ever been more proud of myself. It was the very first time in my [adult] life that I was completely substance free. But mentally I was a wreck. I was so painfully depressed and could barely muster up the motivation to complete the simplest of tasks, like take a shower or make a cup of coffee. Physically I felt great but mentally I felt completely useless. After such an incredible accomplishment, I went and threw it all away by ordering some kratom online to help with my depression and lack of motivation. Before I knew it,I was redosing compulsively throughout the entire day and it only took a couple weeks until I was taking well over 20gpd and waking up in the middle of the night with RLS until I'd get out of bed and redose. I felt more trapped than ever and I felt so ashamed of myself for making it so far just to throw it all away. 

The complete lack of energy and motivation was what did me in. I felt completely useless and I was starting to fail at my business because I had no drive whatsoever. But in hindsight, I can see that I was so much closer than I realized. Had I just stuck it out after those first 30 days, I am sure that things would have only continued to get better and better from that point on. And by this time, I would be feeling better and stronger than ever. But instead I made a full 360 and am right back where I started. My kratom addiction became so out of hand and was wreaking havoc on my physical and mental health as well as having devastating effects on my appearance (extreme hair loss, deep wrinkles, muscle loss, etc) I was helplessly addicted and ultimately returned to Suboxone out of complete desperation. After 113 days of being completely off of it, here I am right back where I started. Talk about feeling defeated. 

My point is this, by using Vitamin C to make my withdrawal period easy and virtually painless, I was far less reluctant to throw away my progress. Vitamin C made it so easy for me to get off of Suboxone that I figured, what's the big deal if I have to start over again? And now I understand exactly what that gentleman meant when he said that he *needed* to experience the pain of withdrawal as it would later serve as his motivator to stay clean. I used Vitamin C powder and it made my detox a cake walk but in the end, is that truly such a good thing? Had I grit my teeth and sweat through weeks of sleepless nights to make it to 30 days, I'm quite certain I would have been far more reluctant to throw it away.

Anyways, I just wanted to share this experience 
because after wanting everyone to know how amazing and effective Vitamin C powder truly is, I felt obligated to share what was a truly unforeseen down side to making withdrawal "easy". No pain no gain I suppose.
